page.title: 09Buildings in Hadstock
page.content: The centre of Hadstock is a triangular village green, from which roads and short lanes lead off in several directions. Most of the houses in the village are several hundreds of years old. Some are plastered, over a timber frame; one large house has exposed vertical studwork. There is a cottage clad in overlapping horizontal boards, treated with dark brown stain. Most old houses still have old windows, with many small panes of glass in frames which slide horizontally to open. Roofs are of tile, some flat, some wavy pantiles; a few are thatched. The old schoolhouse is used as a village hall. Once there was a thriving market and several inns; the King's Head is the only public house now.
